title: Heres a idea
body:
Hey so i had this idea before but my idea of banning or suspending players is that we have a system that if your at least Diamond 3 to Challenger you have a choose to watch a game that has been reported for toxic behaviour, trolling, cheating etc... to see if it's true because the people i tend to report are REALLY toxic and they don't get punished but that was my idea that i would like to share.
P.S It's like CS:GO they have a system called OverWatch to review the match to see if someone is trolling or cheating etc.. i wouldn't mind if League would have it that means i would like to get to Diamond next year ahah

replies.body:
There used to be a tribunal where League Players would read reports and chat logs etc and the community would decide punishments.

Riot removed it (because it was a broken system) and never really replaced it well. The only thing that gets picked up now is verbal abuse (racial, homophobia etc) and when inting is more than obvious (as in 4-5 games in a row of clear int).

Other than that, most people will go unpunished for a long time until they get reported enough that the system finally looks into them

It's not so much a matter of getting reported enough to look into them, but enough valid reports that the system is confident they're actually inting and not just bad. The regrettable result being that the sneaky inters take much longer than anyone would like (except them I suppose) to see punishment. I agree, it isn't up to scratch, though I can respect the reality there.

As for tribunal, it was removed because punishments were almost always too harsh, and the system required almost universal Riot oversight anyway, which kind of defeated the purpose of player driven review. 

It's just not practically possible to get enough people to bother creating such a system to both agree on guidelines and therefore punishments and have motivation to review games without the rewards corrupting the objectivity. The automated system has it's flaws, but it's much fairer and can punish much faster (which is a plus for reform and not just those affected by the behaviour) than tribunal ever could.

i don't care about rewards my reward would be suspending the players/ banning cause i want this game to feel right and punish those players that give REALLY good players the chance to get to they ranks

That wasn't the only reason tribunal failed. Many of the players who would have (and likely still would) participate with no rewards at all tend to be rather vengeful, myself included, and would punish too harshly without considering things like punishment and behavioural history.

The population of players who can be consistently objective, would be willing to participate for no personal gain, and understand the policies in place to punish appropriately is miniscule. It's just not sustainable.

> Other than that, most people will go unpunished for a long time until they get reported enough that the system finally looks into them

The tribunal was terrible. It offered IP for participation (bribery), and encouraged a _certain group_ of people to participate. Mostly, those who like to spite others.
All you did was have to make a judgement to recieve IP rewards, and the more you can get through in an hour, the more IP you received. Why read a report when you can just ctrl-f for a few words and click punish if they come up, regardless of context.
That's how tribunal worked.
You'd see incredibly harsh punishments for very minor offenses.
I say this as a player who had an account permabanned via tribunal back on NA server in season 2.
I have never been banned since.

I didn't say it was good, I was simply saying it existed. OP is asking about players being able to judge other players; I was simply informing him it had existed earlier and was removed (for good reasons).

I wasn't judging your statement, just explaining why such a system fails.
We all good bro.

It is not financially viable to employ people to watch full replays of games (like some suggest) to make a judgement. How many reports would Riot get a day? No system is perfect, you just go with the best on offer.

To be honest, the current system may be flawed, but is more just than the old tribunal.
I believe the appropriate quote is "it's better to let 10 guilty men go free than to imprison a single innocent man" or something like that. It may have been death penalty related originally, which kind of relates to perma-bans.
